Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Masculinity and Fatherhood in Post-trauma and Post-conflict Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social science research on factors that affect family well-being in post-conflict settings has tended to neglect the caregiving roles of adolescent and young adult men. Instead, researchers have attended more to male deficits, recognizing men for the damages they impart via their absence or harmful behaviors rather than for any positive contributions they might make within the family. This gap in knowledge is problematic because it impedes the development of effective and culturally appropriate post-conflict and post-trauma interventions to promote family well-being, provide for child health and resilience, and prevent the intergenerational transmission of violence that might feed future conflicts. Therefore, Yale University doctoral student Kristen McLean, under the supervision of Dr. Catherine Panter-Brick, will undertake research to address this issue.

The researcher has chosen the Kono District of Sierra Leone as an appropriate site to investigate the post-conflict and post-trauma family roles of younger men. This is an appropriate site because the region was particularly devastated by the country's 1991-2002 civil war and has also been affected by the Ebola epidemic. The researcher's overarching research question is: does extreme adversity shape young men's masculinity, fatherhood experiences, and family well-being? She will gather data using a variety of anthropological methods, including: participant observation, semi-structured interviews, the administration of standard scales to assess mental health and resilience, the collection of life history narratives, and analysis of archival materials. Findings from this research will deepen understanding of what it means to be a man in a context of debilitating poverty and public health crisis, identifying key challenges young men face as well as resources they rely upon as they assume traditional older adult parenting roles. Study findings also will advance social science theory of masculinity, fatherhood, and resilience, adding to theoretical debates on gender, family well-being, and the role of fathers in child development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In my doctoral dissertation project, I ask: How does surviving war shape young men’s masculinity, fatherhood experiences, and family wellbeing in post-conflict, Ebola-affected Sierra Leone? Since 2013 I have been engaged in this project, studying what is means to be a man in a context of poverty and public health crisis, and the types of fathering roles and responsibilities assumed by men in this setting. My research, based on 15 months of fieldwork that includes participant observation, semi-structured interviews, and life history narratives, identifies key challenges that men face as well as the resources they rely upon in their efforts to parent and to live up to societal, familial, and personal expectations for themselves as men and fathers.

My findings contrast with static hegemonic versions of masculinity, which depict African men as irresponsible or violent. Rather, my work suggests that many young men want to be active parents and loving partners and have a strong sense of responsibility and pride towards their families, despite substantial economic and social barriers. Findings demonstrate that the most substantial challenges faced by young men include: poverty and economic instability; “contested” relationships with intimate partners, family members, and the law; and the emotional distress derived from these and other factors. In fact, when men are unable to fulfill normative parental and spousal roles due to structural constraints, they often experience emasculation, shame, and distress that can result in feelings of powerlessness and desperation. However, despite these significant challenges many men are succeeding at—or at least trying—to be engaged and loving fathers and partners. Furthermore, many men are able to achieve personal and family wellbeing by reformulating notions of masculinity(ies) and by maintaining a sense of dignity and hope, which I argue are key drivers of wellbeing in settings of insecurity. In Sierra Leone, men are further strengthened by trust in ‘God’s will’ and by drawing upon emotional and material support from peers, family members, and community leaders.

Findings from this study further reveal shifts in ideologies of masculinity associated with breadwinner status or sexual promiscuity to new “emergent” forms tied to responsibility, sound mind, love, and generosity. Specifically, I argue that masculinity(ies) in this setting—rather than being “in crisis” (as has been argued for other African contexts to explain the consequences of neoliberal threats to male privilege)—reflect explicitly “post-crisis” social realities, including an environment of conflicting human rights discourse and more “traditional” gender norms, which themselves are being constantly reformulated within lived gender relations.

This project informs intergenerational aspects of war and as such has implications for developing culturally relevant policies and interventions that promote family wellbeing and prevent transmissions of violence. As for policy implications, while other applied scholarship has emphasized solutions aimed to “modernize” gender norms, the findings of this study support additional attention to policies that address economic reform, including opportunities for both men and women to overcome the poverty and economic instability that threatens family wellbeing. In today’s world of ever-increasing conflict, families—especially fathers—also provide crucial entry points for promoting healthy and resilient children through interventions that reduce violence and build equitable relations across generations. Indeed, men are important “agents of change” within contexts of adversity and thus warrant more attention for the positive roles they can and do play within their families and communities. As such they should be included in parenting interventions at the family, community, and societal levels.

As for specific outputs, I have presented this work in a variety of contexts, including the International Peace Research Association and the Yale African Studies Council. I also co-organized, with my doctoral supervisor Dr. Catherine Panter-Brick, an international workshop on “Fathers in Conflict” to address some of these themes and discuss how to best implement changes to family interventions in low-resource settings. Over the next several years I plan to turn this research into a publishable book manuscript, as well as a series of journal articles, that will add insight to how gender relations and changing norms of masculinity influence men’s involvement in child rearing and overall family wellbeing.
